State Key Laboratory of Mesoscience and Engineering Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Graphical abstract Developing an efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst is important for the production of pure H2 and carbon nanomaterials. Catalytic cracking of methane offers the possibility of producing these high-value products. For this reason, stabilizing the surface active sites of activated methane by modulating the interaction between metal and support has attracted much attention in the development of hydrotalcite-derived NiAl catalysts. Hence, the influence of Zn content and cracking temperature on the structure and performance of hydrotalcite-derived NiZnAl methane cracking catalysts were investigated. It is shown that alloying Zn with Ni reduces the electron density near Ni atoms, promotes the reduction of mixed metal oxides, producing strong interactions between Ni and support, thus improving the stability of the catalyst during methane decomposition. Thus, this strong interaction between Ni and support stabilized the Ni particle size and inhibited the sintering of Ni during the reaction. The Ni2.7Zn0.3Al can maintain a H2 yield of more than 60 % over a 600 min reaction time at 600 °C. TEM analysis showed that the strong metal support interaction changed the morphology of the deposited carbon, maintained the balance between carbon diffusion and CH4 dissociation, provided more growth sites for carbon nanotubes, and also prevented the rapid deactivation of the catalysts because of carbon encapsulation. This article may provide guidance for the design of Ni-based methane cracking catalysts with excellent stability. Keywords Methane cracking NiZn alloy Hydrogen Carbon nanomaterials Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Energy is a driving force and basis for the development of human society, and with the trend of the global energy crisis intensifying, it is crucial to study how to conserve energy and develop new types of clean energy [1,2]. The combustion of traditional fossil fuels produces a variety of polluting gases, causing environmental and climate degradation. Hydrogen is a clean, renewable energy source that burns without any harmful emissions, so the development of hydrogen energy can effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions and achieve sustainable development [3–5]. Currently, hydrogen is mainly produced by traditional production technologies such as CH4 reforming and coal hydrogen production, but these reaction releases large amounts of carbon dioxide [6]. Although electrolysis of water can produce hydrogen from renewable energy sources without producing carbon dioxide, it is still difficult to become the mainstream technology for H2 production owing to high cost and energy consumption [7]. Hydrogen production from methane cracking has received widespread attention worldwide as a low-carbon emission technology, and the process can yield carbon products such as carbon nanotubes and graphite [8–10]. Because of the stable structure of methane, higher temperatures are necessary for the cleavage of the C-H bond. The catalysts can significantly lower the methane decomposition temperature [11,12]. Among the catalysts used to produce hydrogen from decomposing methane, Fe, Ni, and Co have great catalytic activity. Their unfilled 3d orbitals facilitate the dissociation of methane by gaining access to the electrons of the methane molecule [13–15]. In addition, the low cost and abundant reserves of Fe, Ni, and Co satisfy the conditions for large-scale preparation of catalysts. Ni is among the metals with the excellent catalytic methane cracking activity because of the fast diffusion rate and high solubility for carbon [16,17]. However, Ni-based catalysts are rapidly deactivated under higher temperature methane cracking environments because of carbon accumulation and sintering [18]. The main factors affecting the catalytic performance are additive concentration, metal-support interaction and reaction conditions. The interactions between metal and support of the catalyst modulate the catalyst activity by affecting the electronic state and metal dispersion. Suitable metal-support interactions are determined by the type and content of the additives, the preparation method, and the type of support [19–21]. Strong metal-support interactions can inhibit sintering by stabilizing the Ni metal size and promoting its uniform distribution on the support [22,23]. This can influence the nucleation and growth of carbon nanomaterials during methane cracking [24]. Therefore, modulation of metal-support interactions during catalyst design is essential for obtaining high-performance methane cracking catalysts. Among the preparation methods for Ni-based catalysts, the hydrotalcite derivatization method seems to be an effective way to obtain high-performance catalysts [25–27]. Hydrotalcite is a compound consisting of lamellae of positively charged metal cations assembled with interlayer anions in an ordered manner, also known as layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [28–30]. Because of the atomic level dispersion of the metal atoms, the tunable metal cation species, and the domain-limited effect, a wide variety of inorganic functional materials can be constructed [31,32]. After calcination treatment, LDHs are transformed into mixed metal oxides (MMO) by an intrinsic topologically oriented phase transition and further reduction results in well-dispersed metal-loaded catalysts with uniform particles [33,34]. In recent years, hydrotalcite has shown great application prospects in many fields such as catalysis, biology and electronics [35–37]. Studies have shown that as long as the radius of the trivalent and divalent metal cations in the hydrotalcite laminates is not too different from the ionic radius of Mg2+, they can interact with the hydroxyl group to form covalent bonds, thus forming the hydrotalcite structure [38,39]. Common trivalent metal cations that make up nickel-based hydrotalcites include Al3+, Fe3+ and Cr3+ [40–42]. At present, hydrotalcite-derived Ni-based catalysts for methane cracking have been reported. Chen et al. [25] obtained nickel-based methane cracking catalysts by hydrotalcite derivatization and conventional impregnation, respectively, and found that the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with hydrotalcite as precursor showed good catalytic activity due to strong interactions between metal and support. In addition, the incorporation of the second-phase metal into the structure of hydrotalcite-derived NiAl catalysts can significantly improve the sintering resistance of the metal [43–45]. Cao et al. [45] obtained NiCrAl catalysts with different Cr/Ni ratios by reducing the hydrotalcite precursor and found that the Ni crystal size in the methane cracking reaction was stabilized by alloying Cr with Ni. The results showed that the Ni2.7Cr0.3Al catalyst could maintain a stable hydrogen yield of 70 % for a reaction time of 360 min at 620 ℃. However, the mechanism of metal sintering resistance in methane cracking reaction is still unclear, and there is a lack of research on the metal-support interaction to inhibit Ni particle sintering. Therefore, a clearer exploration of the link between metal-support interactions and catalytic stability is particularly important to guide the design of methane cracking catalysts. Here, Zn was introduced into the NiAl hydrotalcite structure to modulate the metal-support interactions by controlling the Zn content. A series of NiZnAl hydrotalcite were obtained by a hydrothermal method, and Ni3−xZnxAl catalysts with different Zn/Ni ratios were obtained after calcination and reduction. The formation of NiZn alloys and the existence of strong interactions with Al2O3 were demonstrated by XRD, XPS and TPR characterization. The influence of Zn content and cracking temperature on the structure and performance of hydrotalcite-derived NiAl methane cracking catalysts were investigated. The effects of the presence of NiZn alloys on the growth and specific form of carbon was analyzed. The relationship between metal-support interaction and Ni particle size during the methane decomposition was studied. This article may provide guidance for the design of Ni-based methane cracking catalysts with excellent stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials Zn(NO3)2·6H2O(≥99 %) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (≥99 %) were acquired from Xilong Scientific, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 %) were purchased from Aladdin, urea (≥99 %). 2.2 Synthesized of Ni3−xZnxAl catalyst Ni3−xZnxAl LDHs were synthesized using a hydrothermal method. 0.06 mmol of urea and a total of 0.012 mol of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were added to 70 ml of deionized water, stirred homogeneously, and the above solution was added to a 100 ml reactor and kept at 120 °C for12h. As illustrated in Fig. 1 (a), all samples exhibited similar diffraction peaks with the appearance of characteristic peaks located at 2θ about 11°, 23° and 35°, corresponding to (003), (006) and (012) in Takovite (PDF#15–0087 Ni6Al2(OH)16CO3⋅4H2O) [46], respectively, which indicates the successful synthesis of Ni3−xZnxAl LDHs. The appearance of other diffraction peaks associated with Zn was not detected, proving that Zn entered into the hydrotalcite structure [47]. Following calcination at 500 °C, the hydrotalcite undergoes a topological transformation to form Ni3−xZnxAl MMO [28]. As shown in Fig. 1(b), all catalysts exhibit characteristic peaks located at 2θ about 37°, 43°, and 62°, which correspond to (101), (012), and (110) in the NiO (PDF#44-1159 Nickel Oxide) [43]. For the calcined Ni3Al MMO samples, the NiO lattice incorporates Al3+, and this kind of NiO phase can be described as an Al-substituted Ni(Al)O oxide solid solution [41,43,44]. Meanwhile, no peaks associated with the element Zn are reflected in the XRD spectra, and no ZnO phase is detected even at Zn contents as high as x = 0.9, which may be due to the highly dispersed state of the Zn species. The XRD spectra of catalysts are shown in Fig. 1(c). The characteristic peaks at 2θ of approximately 76°, 52°, 44°and correspond to the (220), (200), and (111) of metallic Ni (PDF#04-0850), respectively, thereby confirming the successful reduction of Ni species. For the Ni2.1Zn0.9Al sample, a crystalline phase of ZnAl2O4 was identified, which may have been formed due to the interaction of excess Zn with Al2O3. The other samples with low Zn content did not show any diffraction peaks related to the element Al in the reduced XRD spectra. This was attributed to the conversion of Al3+ to amorphous Al2O3 during the reduction process of Ni3−xZnxAl MMO [48]. Notably, the Ni (111) peaks gradually shifted towards the lower 2θ values with increasing Zn content, indicating the formation of NiZn alloys [43,47,49]. The atomic radius of Ni is smaller than that of Zn, and upon entering the Ni metal, Zn atoms cause an enlargement of the Ni lattice [49]. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 1(d), the d111 of the NiZn alloy and its Zn content exhibit a linear relationship, which is consistent with Vegard's law, thereby providing further evidence for the formation of the NiZn alloy [43]. The crystal size of the metal was determined using Scherrer formula based on the half-peak width of the Ni (111) crystal plane in Table 1. The average crystal size of Ni in the Ni3Al was 11 nm. With increasing the Zn content, the metal crystal size in Ni3−xZnxAl catalysts gradually increased. The Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalysts exhibited a maximum crystal size of 13.6 nm. This proves that NiZn alloying promotes an increase in metal crystal size. The specific surface area of the samples was analyzed by BET, and Fig. S2 showed the pore size distributions and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all catalysts. As demonstrated in Fig. S2(a), these catalysts exhibited conventional IV type isotherms with type H3 hysteresis lines, showing that the samples were characterized by slit-like mesoporous structures with plate-like or aggregated particles [24,50,51]. The specific surface area of catalysts is shown in Table 1. The undoped Ni3Al catalyst showed a specific surface area of 89.7 m2/g, while the value of the Ni3−xZnxAl catalyst decreased with increasing of the Zn content. The smallest value of the Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalyst was recorded as 48.4 m2/g. This is consistent with the variation in the crystal size of Ni3−xZnxAl, and the larger crystal size may be the reason for the decrease in specific surface area. However, the results of the performance tests demonstrated that the specific surface area of the samples did not correlate with catalytic stability and activity. Consequently, it was deduced that the specific surface area of the catalysts was not the primary factor influencing catalytic performance. The pore size distribution curve of the catalysts is illustrated in Fig. S2(b). All samples exhibited single-peak distribution characteristics, with pore sizes distributed between 2 and 30 nm, thereby directly substantiating the mesoporous characteristics. It is evident that the pore size of the catalyst increases with the rise in the Zn content, which may be more conducive to methane entering the interior of the catalyst for the reaction. The elemental distribution and surface morphology of catalysts were observed by SEM and EDS, as demonstrated in Fig. S3. Fig. S3(1) presents the SEM image of the hydrotalcite precursor, and it was determined that Ni3Al LDHs exhibited a nanoflower-like structure in Fig. S3(a1). In Fig. S3(a1)-Fig. S3(e1), the nanosheets of Ni3−xZnxAl LDHs undergo an expansion in size with an increase in the amount of Zn, while demonstrating a shift from aggregated nanoflowers to dispersed nanosheets. This structural modification may be the underlying cause of the diminished specific surface area of the Ni3−xZnxAl. Fig. S3(2) presented the image of the catalyst following reduction. It was found that the Ni3−xZnxAl catalyst maintained the nanosheet structure of the hydrotalcite precursor even after the high-temperature reduction process at 800 °C, which highlights the advantage of the high-temperature structural stability of hydrotalcite. The higher magnification SEM image (Fig. S4) revealed the presence of uniform-sized metal particles distributed on the surface of the reduced Ni3−xZnxAl compared to the hydrotalcite precursor, thereby substantiating the successful reduction of Ni species from the precursor. It is noteworthy that increasing the Zn content results in a gradual increase in the size of the metal particles, aligning with the conclusions drawn from XRD. Furthermore, the EDS elemental mapping results presented in Fig. S3(2) demonstrate that Ni, Al and Zn are highly dispersed within the catalyst. The surface properties of the Ni3−xZnxAl catalysts were analyzed by XPS. Fig. 2 (a) displays the Ni2p XPS spectra of all catalysts after reduction. Based on the binding energies of the Ni2p XPS, it can be determined that two valence states of Ni species exist in all samples. This indicates that the Ni species in the catalyst is not fully reduced, which may be due to the presence of difficult to reduce substances in the sample or oxidation of the sample during preparation [52–54]. The Ni2p peaks at 852 eV and 869 eV for the reduced samples are attributed to Ni0, whereas the Ni2+ peaks are at 856.0 eV and 873 eV, in agreement with the literature reports [50,55]. Notably, the intensity of Ni0 peaks is significantly stronger for the Zn-containing catalysts compared to the Ni3Al catalysts, suggesting that the addition of Zn improves the degree of reduction and facilitates the reduction of more Ni0 from the precursor. Specifically, the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst showed a higher Ni0 peak intensity as well as a lower Ni2+ peak, indicating that the Ni content in Ni2.7Zn0.3Al is relatively high. Furthermore, there is a shift of the Ni0 peak towards higher energies in the NiZnAl compared with the Ni3Al. The shift is attributed to a decrease in the electron density of the nickel metal due to the low coordination effect of the Ni atoms, suggesting an improvement in the electron exchange between the NiZn alloy and the support in the NiZnAl catalyst [24,56–58]. As demonstrated in Fig. S5(a), an increase in the Zn content from 0 to 0.3 resulted in a shift of the Ni0 peak towards higher energies. The Ni0 peak exhibited the most significant shift in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalysts, indicating a robust interaction between the NiZn alloy and Al2O3 in these catalysts [59]. Conversely, when the Zn content was elevated from 0.3 to 0.9, the Ni0 peak underwent a shift towards the low-energy direction, indicating that the substantial presence of Zn diminished the metal support interaction. This phenomenon may be attributed to the strong interaction of excess Zn with the Al2O3 [24], which is consistent with the presence of ZnAl2O4 in the Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalyst, as evidenced by XRD in Fig. 1(c). The Ni 2p3/2 of Ni3Al and Ni2.7Zn0.3Al are displayed in Fig. 2(b), where an increase of the Ni0 peak from 852.6 eV for Ni3Al to 852.8 eV for Ni2.7Zn0.3Al can be observed. Higher binding energies indicate the appearance of stronger interactions between the Ni and the Al2O3. Furthermore, the relative contents of Ni0 and Ni2+ were confirmed based on the peak areas, revealing that only 29 % of Ni0 was present in the Ni3Al catalyst, whereas 41 % of Ni0 was present in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst. This suggests that the appearance of Zn enhances the reduction of Ni species. The Zn2p spectrum of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst, as depicted in Fig. S5(b), exhibits peaks at 1044.7 eV and 1021.7 eV, ascribed to Zn2p 3/2 and Zn2p 1/2. A discrepancy of 23 eV in the binding energies of these peaks is indicative of the presence of Zn0 [60–62]. The O1s XPS spectra of Ni3Al and Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(c). The peak located near 531.3 eV is considered to be reactive oxygen species on defects such as O2– and is associated with oxygen vacancies. The presence of oxygen vacancies plays an important role in removing the generated coke and limiting particle sintering to maintain good catalytic stability [24,63–65]. The binding energy in connection with chemisorbed oxygen increases from 531.3 eV for Ni3Al catalyst to 531.5 eV for Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst, suggesting that Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst produces more superoxide and higher reactivity than Ni3Al catalyst [66–68]. In Fig. 2(d), the presence of Zn improves the binding energy of Al2p spectra. This shows a strong interaction between Al2O3 and the NiZn alloy. The electron-rich interface created between the metal and the support is significant for stabilizing the active sites and can promote the stability during the methane cracking reaction [24]. To further investigate the metal support interactions, the reduction of Ni and Zn was analyzed by using H2-TPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The Ni3Al samples showed a peak in the 450–800 °C, which was because of the reduction of Ni2+ in the samples [69]. With the addition of Zn, the sample still retained an H2 consumption peak, indicating the co-reduction process of Ni2+ and Zn2+ in the NiZnAl catalyst [47]. In addition, the peak temperatures of Ni3Al, Ni2.85Zn0.15Al, Ni2.7Zn0.3Al, Ni2.4Zn0.6Al and Ni2.1Zn0.9Al calcined samples were 666 °C, 685 °C, 702 °C, 696 °C and 688 °C, indicating that the peak reduction temperatures showed a tendency to increase and then decrease with increasing Zn content. This result shows that Zn promotes the interaction between Ni and Al2O3 [49], with the strongest metal support interaction in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al sample. However, excess Zn forms the difficult to reduce ZnAl2O4 species with Al2O3, thus weakening the metal-support interaction, consistent with the results of Ni 2p XPS spectra in Fig. S5(a) and XRD in Fig. 1(c). 3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation To investigate the implication of NiZn alloying on the performance of catalysts, H2 production from CH4 catalytic cracking tests were conducted for 400 min at GHSV = 18000 mL/ (h gcat) and 650 °C. The performance curves of reaction time and H2 yield for different catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 (a). The Ni3Al was deactivated after 60 min, and the H2 yield had decreased to 15 % after 200 min of reaction. This was due to the reaction of methane with the catalyst and the deposition of carbon atoms hindering further contact between the CH4 and catalyst [45]. The catalytic performance of Ni3Al changed significantly after NiZn alloying. Based on H2-TPR, by increasing the Zn content, the metal support interaction became stronger at higher temperatures, which may have prevented the sintering of the Ni, thus promoting the catalytic stability. When the Zn content was increased from 0 to 0.3, the catalytic stability was improved, and the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst could maintain a stable H2 yield of more than 60 % for 250 min of reaction. This can be due to adding Zn affecting the mesoporous structure of the catalyst, which facilitates the full contact between Ni and CH4. According to the XPS analysis, the Zn in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al increased the reduction of Ni species in the catalyst and provided more active sites. In addition, the vacancy oxygen-related peaks are shifted to higher energies, resulting in generating more superoxide, which promotes the decomposition of methane [70]. Combined with TPR and XPS analyses, Ni2.7Zn0.3Al showed strong interactions between metal and support in all samples, which potentially restrained the sintering of the Ni, thus demonstrating to have the best catalytic performance [71,72]. As the Zn content continued to increase from 0.3 to 0.9, the catalytic activity decreased, which could be attributed to the decrease in the specific surface area because of excess Zn. In addition, according to XRD and TPR analyses, Zn interacted with Al2O3 to form ZnAl2O4 and weakened the metal-support interaction in the Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalysts to affect the catalytic activity. Fig. 4(b) shows the H2 yields of different catalysts initially and after 300 min of reaction. The initial H2 yield of NiZnAl catalyst slightly decreased with the increase of Zn. The Ni3Al exhibited the initial H2 yield of 73.1 %, which could be attributed to the higher Ni content. After 300 min reaction, the H2 yield of Ni3Al catalyst decreased from 73.1 % to 10.3 %, while the hydrogen yield of Ni3−xZnxAl catalyst exhibited a volcano distribution with increasing Zn content, and the H2 yield of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst decreased from 72.0 % to 41.1 %, proving that the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst exhibits excellent stability. This is mainly because of the interaction between the NiZn alloy and Al2O3 as well as the structural electronic effect, leading to stable methane adsorption sites and effectively prevents the deactivation [72]. To study the influence of cracking temperature on the catalytic performance of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalysts, the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalysts were reacted at 700 °C and 600 °C, respectively, and the H2 yields were also compared with those at 650 °C in Fig. 4(c). When the reaction temperature was increased to 700 °C, the H2 yield of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst increased to 78 %, which demonstrated the endothermic reaction [8]. Nevertheless, the catalyst was deactivated after maintaining 60 min, indicating that the higher cracking temperature increased the catalytic activity while decreasing the stability. The initial H2 yield of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al was reduced to 62 % at 600 °C, but the stability was significantly improved, retaining more than 60 % hydrogen yield for 600 min, and after 1000 min of reaction, the H2 yield was still 35 %. This suggests that the lower cracking temperature reduces the catalytic activity but increases the stability. These results indicate that the cracking temperature significantly has a significant effect on the stability and activity. The stability depends on two factors: the methane dissociation and the diffusion of carbon [73,74]. Since methane cracking is an endothermic reaction, increasing the cracking temperature significantly promotes methane conversion. When the dissociation rate of methane far exceeds the diffusion rate of carbon, the deposited carbon rapidly deactivates the catalyst by covering the active sites. Similarly, at lower cracking temperatures, when the diffusion rate of carbon matches the dissociation rate of methane, the catalyst shows good stability [27,74,75]. As shown in Table S1, the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst in this work exhibits good catalytic performance in terms of stability and hydrogen yield compared to other hydrotalcite-derived Ni-based catalysts in the literature. 3.3 Analyze of spent catalysts The crystal structures of the reacted catalysts were studied by XRD. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), at 650 °C, diffraction peaks of (002) crystal faces of carbon species appeared at a diffraction angle of 26.1° for all Ni3−xZnxAl, except for the peak of Ni. This proves the formation of deposited carbon [76]. In addition, Ni2.4Zn0.6Al and Ni2.1Zn0.9Al spent catalysts exhibited characteristic peaks at 2θ of about73°, 49°, and 44°, which corresponded to the (220), (200), and (111) crystalline plane in Nickel Zinc Carbide (PDF#28–0713 Ni3ZnC0.7), respectively. This proves that Ni2.4Zn0.6Al and Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalysts formed metal carbides during the reaction process. The formation of Ni3ZnC0.7 further confirms the formation of NiZn alloys. The absence of Ni3ZnC0.7 in low Zn content spent catalysts implies that Zn content is the key factor for Ni3ZnC0.7 formation at 650 °C. Notably, the detection of metal carbide formation in Ni-based spent catalysts for methane cracking is rare. Generally, the Fe3C phase is present in Fe-based methane cracking spent catalysts [77–79]. Zhou et al. [80] studied the CH4 cracking process on Fe-based catalysts and found that Fe3C and graphitic carbon were formed by the decomposition of unstable supersaturated iron carbide. However, the reaction mechanisms of Ni and Fe are different. The methane cracking reaction on Ni-based catalysts is assumed to be a three-step process: activated decomposition of CH4 on Ni to generate carbon and H2, diffusion and precipitation of carbon. During diffusion, carbon dissolves into Ni to form a metal carbide, but this metal carbide is unstable and will further decompose into Ni and deposited C at the metal-support interface [81], leading to producing only carbon in the spent catalyst, consistent with the XRD of Ni3Al in Fig. 5(a). However, metal carbide formation may occur in the spent catalyst after alloying the second phase metal with Ni. Alharthi et al. [82] studied the formation of Fe2NiC phase in the cracking of CH4 over NiFe2O4/Al2O3 and the authors attributed the absence of the metal active phase because of the formation of Fe2NiC for the low catalytic activity. This also explains the reduced catalytic activity of Ni2.4Zn0.6Al and Ni2.1Zn0.9Al catalysts in Fig. 4(a), where NiZn alloy and C interacted during the reaction to form Ni3ZnC0.7, which resulted in the loss of a portion of active site, resulting in deactivation. This proves that the Ni3ZnC0.7 species is not catalytically active for methane cracking. Fig. 5(b) exhibits the XRD of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al after reaction at 600 °C, 650 °C and 700 °C. The intensity of the peaks of the carbon on the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 600 °C is larger, indicating that a higher amount of carbon accumulation was generated after reaction, consistent with the performance in Fig. 4(c). The Ni3ZnC0.7 phase was present in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst at 600 °C compared to the catalysts after reaction at 650 °C and 700 °C. This demonstrates that in addition to the higher Zn content, the lower reaction temperature is also a factor that promotes the formation of the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase. Raman spectroscopy is a common method to study crystallinity and graphitization of carbon. In Fig. 5, the Raman spectra of all samples showed absorption peaks near 1337 cm−1 and 1566 cm−1, belong to the D band and G band. The D band is mainly because of the structural defects, while the G band is caused by the C–C planar extension vibration in the graphite layer [83,84]. The degree of graphitization is determined by the intensity ratio (ID/IG) of the D band to the G band [85,86]. In Fig. 5(c), the ID/IG value of the carbon deposited on the Ni3Al spent catalyst is 0.72, indicating a high degree of graphitization. With increasing Zn content, the ID/IG of Ni3−xZnxAl spent catalyst becomes larger, indicating Zn increasing the defects in the spent catalyst. In addition, with increasing Zn content, the G-band of Ni3−xZnxAl spent catalyst shows a significant blue shift, which may be due to the abundance of defects. Fig. 5(d) shows the Raman spectra of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at different cracking temperatures, and it was found that the ID/IG of three samples were near 1 and the peaks were not significantly shifted. This indicates that the cracking temperature has a small effect on the degree of graphitization of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst. The morphology of the deposited carbon generated on the catalyst was characterized by SEM. In Fig. 6 (a), the carbon on the Ni3Al is found as particles, and it is difficult to find the presence of carbon nanotubes. From Fig. 6(b) to (e), the carbon nanotubes gradually became more abundant with increasing Zn content, which indicated that Zn improved the formation of carbon nanotubes. The metal-support interaction exerts a significant influence on regulating carbon products from methane cracking. The strong interaction of NiZn alloy with Al2O3 inhibits the carbon–metal interaction, which reduces the encapsulation of carbon [87]. Moreover, the formation of metal carbides has been demonstrated to be a pivotal factor in the process of carbon nanotube growth [81]. Fig. 6(f) and (g) show the SEM images of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalysts at 700 °C and 600 °C. By comparing with the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 650 °C, this revealed a substantial impact of temperature on the morphology of the deposited carbon. In Fig. 6(f), the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst carbon at 600 °C grows as carbon nanotubes, longer in length and interwoven with each other, which corresponds to the excellent stability of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 600 °C in Fig. 4(c). At 650 °C, carbon particles and carbon nanotubes coexisted on the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst in Fig. 6(c). In Fig. 6(g), the carbon on the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst at 700 °C exists exclusively as carbon particles, which explains that the rapid deactivation of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 700 °C is attributable to carbon encapsulation in Fig. 4(c). These indicate that low temperature favors carbon nanotubes and high temperature promotes the growth of carbon particles, which is consistent with previous findings [25,45]. Therefore, regulating the balance between the carbon diffusion and the methane dissociation by controlling the temperature is important for obtaining carbon products with specific morphology. The spent catalyst was subjected to TEM analysis to further analyze the influence of cracking temperature and Zn on the carbon morphology. In Fig. 7 , various carbon structures can be generated according to different catalytic conditions, which is consistent with the conclusion drawn from the SEM in Fig. 6. During the reaction, carbon atoms dissolve into Ni particles to form substable metal carbons, which subsequently decompose at the metal-support interface to generate Ni and C [80,81]. Therefore, the strength of the metal and support interact is a key factor in deciding the type of deposited carbon [88,89]. In Fig. 7(a), the Ni3Al catalyst is susceptible to metal-support separation and eventual formation of carbon particles encapsulated by deposited carbon because of weaker metal-support interaction during continuous carbon deposition. In Fig. 7(b), a hollow tubular structure was found on the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al, which confirming the presence of carbon nanotubes. The metal located at the tips of the carbon nanotubes were encapsulated by the deposited carbon, suggesting a tip-growth model of carbon [27]. This is due to the fact that the presence of Zn enhances the metal-support interaction and restrains the separation of the metal from the support during carbon growth as carbon nanotubes [24,90]. It is evident that, given CH4 cracking is an endothermic reaction, temperature exerts a substantial influence on C diffusion and CH4 dissociation. The carbon deposited on the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst at 600 °C grows exclusively as carbon nanotubes in Fig. 7(c), and the presence of metal particles at the extremities of the carbon nanotubes has not been detected. In the high-resolution TEM of Fig. 7(e), it is evident that the tips of the carbon nanotubes are composed of open graphite rings, with a diameter of approximately 15 nm, a characteristic that is commonly observed in multi-walled carbon nanotubes [45]. These findings suggest that at 600 °C, due to the existence of strong interaction between metal and support in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst, the interaction of carbon with the metal is not sufficient to separate the metal from the support, which leads to the carbon as open carbon nanotubes in the mode of base growth [24,91]. On the contrary, the carbon obtains enough driving force to induce the separation of metal and obtain to form carbon particles at 700 °C in Fig. 7(d), similar to the reaction process of Ni3Al catalyst at 650 °C. In Fig. 7(f), a graphite layer with a thickness of 18.5 nm was found to completely encapsulate the metal particles, which further demonstrates that carbon deposition that prevents the Ni particles and thus the inability to contact methane to carry out the reaction is responsible for rapid deactivation of the catalyst [92]. The thermal stability of the spent catalysts was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis of the samples in an air environment in Fig. 8 . The carbon yield is calculated from the weight ratio of the oxidized weight loss of carbon to the residue after oxidation based on the thermogravimetric curve of the spent catalyst [93]. In Fig. 8(a), there is no significant weight loss of all spent catalysts until 500 °C. This proves the absence of amorphous carbon in the spent catalysts, which has been reported to be generally oxidized before 400 °C [94]. All spent catalysts showed a one-step loss in mass between 500 °C and 800 °C. Carbon removal at higher than 500 °C is considered to be the combustion of graphitic carbon or carbon nanotubes. The presence of carbon nanotubes in the spent catalysts can be determined by combining the TEM analysis [77]. Compared with 61 % weight loss of the Ni3Al, the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst exhibited 74 % mass loss, which corresponded to a carbon yield of 2.84 gc/gcat, indicating Zn increasing carbon deposited on the catalysts by improving the stability. With decreasing cracking temperature, the mass loss of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst increased. The Ni2.7Zn0.3Al spent catalyst after the reaction at 600 ℃ exhibited a maximum mass loss of 89 %, equivalent to a C yield of 8.09 gc/gcat. In addition, there was a slight increase in the mass around 800 °C, which could be due to the Ni oxidation after the oxidation of the deposited carbon, and similar experimental results were obtained by Osman et al. [95]. 3.4 Analysis of metal resistance to sintering Compared with the catalyst in Fig. 1(c), the metal peaks of Ni3−xZnxAl spent catalyst in Fig. 5 are sharper, which indicates that the catalyst becomes larger in crystal size after the reaction. To obtain a more precise understanding of the alterations in the dimensions of the metal particles during the reaction process and the effect of metal support interactions on the change of the Ni particles, the reaction was conducted on Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalysts for 15–60 min at different temperature. In addition, the Ni3Al was also carried out at 650 °C. In Fig. 9 . The peak of Ni was found to become sharp with increasing reaction time, indicating that the Ni particles size gradually became larger. Moreover, in Fig. 9(c), it was found that the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase was present in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 600 °C after 15 min of reaction, indicating that the Ni3ZnC0.7 and the deposited carbon may be generated simultaneously. Zhou et al. [80] investigated the methane cracking process of Fe-based catalysts and found that Fe3C and graphitic carbon formed by the decomposition of unstable supersaturated iron carbide. Therefore, it is assumed that the Ni3ZnC0.7 phase is generated by decomposition of supersaturated metal carbides. Notably, the Ni diffraction peaks shifted to a small angle as the reaction progressed. Shaikhutdinov et al. [96] also found a shift of Ni peaks towards a small angle for the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts by in situ XRD at 550 °C. This shift may be caused by the dissolution of C into the metal lattice, since the vacancies in the Ni lattice (0.52Å) is smaller than the radius of carbon atoms (0.77Å) [43]. The metal lattice constants were calculated from the diffraction peaks of the Ni (111) crystal plane. Fig. S6 exhibits the change of Ni lattice constant with reaction time. The Ni3Al catalyst and Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst were found to exhibit similar changes in lattice constants at 650 °C. The Ni diffraction peaks were shifted to a small angle and the corresponding lattice constants became larger within 15 min of the reaction of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst at 650 °C, which can be interpreted as diffusion of carbon into the Ni lattice. It then shifted back to the initial position within 15–60 min, which could mean that carbon atoms precipitated to form deposited carbon, leading to a decrease in C dissolved in the metal lattice. In contrast, the Ni peak of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst at 600 °C exhibited a gradual shift to a lower angle within 60 min of reaction, and the corresponding Ni lattice constant increased from 0.3528 nm to 3536 nm, which was much larger than that of Ni3Al catalyst and Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst at 650 °C. This suggests that extensive C atoms were dissolved in the Ni lattice of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al at 600 °C, which may be the reason for the formation of Ni3ZnC0.7. The Ni crystal size was calculated through the Ni (111) by the Scherrer formula. The variation of metal crystal size during the reaction was plotted in Fig. 9(d). The metal crystal size increased with increasing reaction time. Notably, all catalysts retained about 11 nm Ni crystal size of after 240 min reduction at 800 °C, while Ni rapidly sintered after reacting at 650 °C. This implies that the sintering is caused by the entry of C into the crystal lattice after the contact of metal with methane. Compared to the Ni3Al catalyst where the Ni crystal size increased from 11 nm at the beginning of the reaction to 23.5 nm after 60 min of reaction, the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst at 650 °C showed an increase in crystal size from 12.2 nm at the beginning of the reaction to 21.5 nm after 60 min of reaction, which indicates that NiZn alloying inhibited the sintering of the catalyst. The XPS and TPR exhibited that a robust interaction was observed between the metal and the support in the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst, which might be responsible for the inhibition of metal sintering [24]. Moreover, the Ni size of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al increased from 12.2 nm to 19.8 nm at 600 °C. This suggests that the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst exhibits a good resistance to sintering at lower cracking temperatures. Considering in conjunction with the performance curves analyzed in Fig. 4, the Ni3Al catalyst demonstrated a swift decline in H2 yield after 60 min of reaction at 650 °C. This may be attributed to Ni metal sintering. The Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst exhibited a reduced rate of deactivation in comparison to the Ni3Al catalyst, attributable to the presence of a NiZn alloying effect, which hindered metal sintering. Consequently, the sintering rate of the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al catalyst was found to be lower than that of the Ni3Al catalyst. Furthermore, at reaction temperatures of 600 °C, the reduced sintering rate of Ni2.7Zn0.3Al relative to that of Ni3Al catalysts resulted in diminished deactivation of the catalyst, thereby demonstrating notable catalytic stability. Consequently, the correlation between metal crystal size and H2 yield is evident. Moderate doping of Zn and lowering of the reaction temperature can effectively inhibit the sintering of the metal during the reaction and stabilize the active sites on the surface of the catalyst, thereby enhancing the catalytic stability performance. 4 Conclusions In this paper, the performance of a series of Ni3−xZnxAl (x = 0, 0.15, 0.3, 0.6, 0.9) catalysts for methane cracking was investigated with a focus on the effects of Zn/Ni ratio and cracking temperature. Ni3−xZnxAl hydrotalcites were obtained by a hydrothermal method, and uniformly dispersed Ni3−xZnxAl catalysts were obtained after calcination and reduction. The findings demonstrated that the Ni2.7Zn0.3Al exhibited optimal performance. and was able to maintain a stable hydrogen yield of more than 60 % within 250 min of reaction at 650 °C. The impact of temperature on the performance of catalytic cracking of methane was found to be significant. Higher cracking temperature favor higher catalytic activity, while lower temperatures promote the stability of catalyst. The Ni2.7Zn0.3Al can maintain a H2 yield of more than 60 % over a 600 min reaction time at 600 °C. TEM showed that the catalyst was accompanied by carbon nanotubes present in a base growth mode. Characterization by XRD, XPS and TPR showed that Zn promoted the reduction of mixed metal oxides by alloying with Ni, reducing the electron density near Ni atoms and creating strong interactions between Ni and Al2O3, which improved the stability of the catalyst during methane decomposition. Moreover, this strong interaction between metal and support stabilized the metal particle size and inhibited the sintering of Ni, while changing the morphology of the deposited carbon, maintaining the balance between carbon diffusion and methane dissociation, and providing more growth sites for carbon nanotubes. Therefore, it is crucial to promote the stability of methane cracking catalysts and to prepare high-quality carbon nanotubes by regulating the interaction between metal and support. coredata.dc:description: Developing an efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst is important for the production of pure H2 and carbon nanomaterials. Catalytic cracking of methane offers the possibility of producing these high-value products. For this reason, stabilizing the surface active sites of activated methane by modulating the interaction between metal and support has attracted much attention in the development of hydrotalcite-derived NiAl catalysts. Hence, the influence of Zn content and cracking temperature on the structure and performance of hydrotalcite-derived NiZnAl methane cracking catalysts were investigated. It is shown that alloying Zn with Ni reduces the electron density near Ni atoms, promotes the reduction of mixed metal oxides, producing strong interactions between Ni and support, thus improving the stability of the catalyst during methane decomposition. Thus, this strong interaction between Ni and support stabilized the Ni particle size and inhibited the sintering of Ni during the reaction. The Ni2.7Zn0.3Al can maintain a H2 yield of more than 60 % over a 600 min reaction time at 600 °C. TEM analysis showed that the strong metal support interaction changed the morphology of the deposited carbon, maintained the balance between carbon diffusion and CH4 dissociation, provided more growth sites for carbon nanotubes, and also prevented the rapid deactivation of the catalysts because of carbon encapsulation. This article may provide guidance for the design of Ni-based methane cracking catalysts with excellent stability.
